definition: oneness of heaven and humanity/the theory that man is an integral part of nature
day/sky/heaven
man/person/people/CL:個|个[ge4],位[wei4]
100 ml/one-tenth of a peck/measure for dry grain equal to one-tenth of sheng 升 or liter, or one-hundredth dou 斗
to close/to join/to fit/to be equal to/whole/together/round (in battle)/conjunction (astronomy)/1st note of pentatonic scale/old variant of 盒[he2]
variant of 合[he2]
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit

sentences.english: The general principle of Chinese world view and culture is the harmony between the heaven and human.
sentences.chinese: 中国的宇宙观和文化总纲是天人合一。

sentences.english: "Exhaustion of nature" in Confucianism becomes the human-nature-unity systematic theory.
sentences.chinese: 儒家的“尽性”学说，成为天人合一的系统理论。

sentences.english: As "ZhuangShengXiao fan butterfly dream", nature and humanity.
sentences.chinese: 就如同同“庄生晓梦迷蝴蝶”，天人合一。

sentences.english: Don't tell me that eating raw meat like a primitive person is the best way to be.
sentences.chinese: 天人合一，难道生活在茹毛饮血的原始时代才是最好？

sentences.english: Hence, the poet can enter the aesthetic world of " man and heaven in one" .
sentences.chinese: 所以，诗人能达到“天人合一”的艺术境界。

sentences.english: Chinese medicine for man and nature live in harmony super-giant system theory analysis.
sentences.chinese: 中医天人合一的超巨系统理论等综合分析。

definition: interactions between heaven and mankind (Han Dynasty doctrine)
Daoist School of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC), based on the teachings of Laozi or Lao-tze 老子[Lao3 zi3] (c. 500 BC-) and Zhuangzi 庄子 (369-286 BC)
to return to one's true self/to regain the natural state
boundary/state/realm
artistic mood or conception/creative concept
world view
to grow old with unfailing eyes and ears (idiom)
inner transcendence (perfection through one's own inner moral cultivation, as in Confucianism, for example)
the Absolute or Supreme Ultimate, the source of all things according to some interpretations of Chinese mythology
mystery within a mystery/the mysteries of the Dao according to Laozi 老子[Lao3 zi3]
yin and yang
The Book of Changes ("I Ching")
to study the underlying principle to acquire knowledge (idiom); pursuing knowledge to the end
to die (Buddhism)
the real essence (of the matter)
nature (the natural world)
